chapter.title: Default Installation Scenarios
chapter.para: After planning the installation with downloading the software and checking the minimal hardware requirements, there are three default installation scenarios:

sect1.title: Planning the Installation
sect1.para: Plan the installation with downloading the software and checking the minimal hardware requirements.

step.para: Download the DVD ISO image of &sles4sap; 11 (electronic media kit).
Burn the image onto a physical DVD and ensure that it is bootable. Alternatively, you might use a virtual CD-ROM device for installation into a virtual machine.

listitem.para: For the Installation with Wizard, at least 60 GB hard disk space for the system volume and 200 GB for the data partition.

sect1.title: Booting the Installation Medium
sect1.para: Different scenarios are available to install &slsreg; for SAP Applications 11. Select the preferred installation scenario from the DVD boot menu:

listitem.para: Booting the system installed on the local hard disk.
Basically a standard SLES installation prepared for installing SAP applications later. You can install SAP applications with 3rd party installation routines.
This scenario is suitable for experienced administrators who want to install &sles4sap; according to their own plan.

varlistentry.term: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard (see )

listitem.para: This is a guided installation of the operating system and the SAP applications. After the installation of the operating system the SAP Installation Wizard (Media-Changer) will start for installation of a validated SAP solution.

varlistentry.term: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile (see )

listitem.para: This installation is driven by a user-provided &ay; profile. There are no &suse;-provided SAP optimizations.
This scenario is suitable for experienced users who are familiar with &ay; and want to deploy their own &ay; profiles to install &sles4sap;.
Starting a minimal Linux system without a graphical user interface. For more information, see the &admin;, Chapter 34, Common Problems and Their Solutions.
Testing the system RAM using repeated read and write cycles. For more information, see the &admin; Chapter 34, Common Problems and Their Solutions.

sect1.para:
The first part is similar to a standard manual &sls; installation; for details about such an SLES installation, see the SLES &deploy;, Chapter 6, Installation with &yast;.
In addition, the SAP Application Server Base (sap-loc and sapconf) pattern will be installed by default and basic settings will be configured.
You will be prompted for all common installation settings, like partitioning of storage devices, network, or software packages.

title.guimenu: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard

sect1.para: This is a guided installation of the operating system with optimized settings for SAP applications.
During this installation scenario, the following installation and configuration steps will take place and interactive settings are possible:

sect2.title: Selecting SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard from the DVD Boot Menu
sect2.para: From the DVD boot menu (see ), select SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard. The installation process loads and configures a minimal Linux system to run the installation procedure. To view the boot messages and copyright notices during this process, press Esc. On completion of this process, the &yast; installation program starts and displays the graphical installer, which will run mostly automatically.

sect2.title: Preparing System for Automated Installation
sect2.para: After analyzing your computer, the next &yast; pop-up dialog will let you specify the volume configuration. Here you configure the volume for the system and swap space. The data volume comes later, after you select the SAP Application.
If there is just one hard disk, keep it as the system volume device and set the size of the system volume (and the swap space) in GB in the lower field and confirm it; see .

tip.title: Size of the System Volume
tip.para: At least 60 GB is required for the system volume. The swap space depends on the available main memory (RAM). For more information, see the SAP Note 1597355: .

sect2.para: If there is more than one hard disk, select the right one as the system volume device and set the size of the system volume (and the swap space) in GB in the lower fields and confirm it.

warning.title: Deleting Data
warning.para: If you confirm the storage volume configuration, all existing data on the hard disk will be deleted. If you do not want this to happen, turn off the system.

sect2.para: After confirmation, &yast; performs the software installation. Packages are installed one by one, so you can see the progress.

sect2.title: Password for the System Administrator &rootuser;
sect2.para: When all packages are installed, the basic installation is finished, and the system is rebooted for initial configuration, you will be prompted to enter a Password for the System Administrator &rootuser;; see .

&rootuser; is the name of the superuser, or the administrator of the system. Unlike regular users (who may or may not have permission to access certain areas or execute certain commands on the system), &rootuser; has unlimited access to change the system configuration, install programs, and set up new hardware. The &rootuser; account should only be used for system administration, maintenance, and repair. Logging in as &rootuser; for daily work is rather risky: a single mistake could lead to irretrievable loss of system files.
For verification purposes, the password for &rootuser; must be entered twice. Do not forget the &rootuser; password. Once entered, this password cannot be retrieved.
The &rootuser; password can be changed any time later in the installed system. To do so, run &yast; and start Security and Users User and Group Management .

warning.title: The root User
warning.para: The &rootuser; user has all the permissions needed to make changes to the system. To carry out such tasks, the &rootuser; password is required. You cannot carry out any administrative tasks without this password.

sect2.title: Hostname, Domain Name, and IP Address
sect2.para: The next dialog starts with the network configuration; see .

figure.title: Hostname, Domain Name, and IP Address

sect2.para: The Hostname is the computer’s name in the network. The Domain Name is the name of the network. A hostname and domain are proposed by default. If your system is part of a network, the hostname has to be unique in this network, whereas the domain name has to be common to all hosts on the network.
Also enter the IP Address and Netmask for this host. The IP address must be unique and the netmask has to be common to all hosts on the network.

sect2.title: Domain Name Service (DNS) and Time Server (NTP)
sect2.para: The next dialog continues with the network configuration; see .

figure.title: Domain Name Service (DNS) and Time Server (NTP)

sect2.para: For Domain Name Service (DNS) configuration, enter the Domain Searchlist and the IP Address of DNS Server plus the IP address of the Default Gateway of your network.
Also enter the address of the NTP Server to synchronize automatically via Network Time Protocol (NTP).

sect2.title: Registration
sect2.para: To get technical support and product updates, you need to register and activate your product with the &ncc;; see . This dialog provides assistance for doing so. Find detailed information about &ncc; at .

Enter your E-Mail Address and Registration Code for the product. If you provide the registration code now, operating system updates will be installed automatically during the installation of the system.

sect2.title: System Configuration Settings
sect2.para: After confirming the registration data, the system will be configured with the supplied settings.
No user action is required at this stage.

warning.title: Firewall Disabled
warning.para: This wizard-based installation scenario disables the firewall (SuSEfirewall2) completely.

If needed, you can activate the firewall after the installation. If you activate the firewall after the installation, you must open all required ports manually. For more information about required ports, see .

sect2.title: SAP Product Installation
sect2.para: After applying the configuration settings, you are prompted to continue with the SAP Product Installation using the SAP Installation Wizard. The SAP Installation Wizard will install the SAP application from the SAP media kits you received from SAP. It covers BOBJ and Netweaver.

Confirm the pop-up (see ), if you want to continue with the installation right away. On the other hand, it is possible to interrupt the installation process at this point and resume it after a system restart.

tip.title: Resuming SAP Installation after System Restart
tip.para: To resume the SAP installation with the wizard, start &yast; and select the SAP Product Installer (Computer, then in the YaST Control Center click MiscellaneousSAP Product Installer; see ). The functionality is the same, but the layout of the dialogs is different; the left progress pane is only displayed, if continue with the installation without a restart.
The following screen shots document the installation with the SAP Product Installer that runs after a restart of the system.

sect2.para: In the next dialog provide the Location of the SAP Installation Master (that is the location of the medium, which is called Business Suite — Installation Master); see . The location could be a local source (directory (dir://), locally connected hard disk (device://), USB mass storage (usb://), or CD-ROM (cdrom://)), or a remotely provided installation source (either NFS (nfs://) or SMB (smb://))—select the corresponding option from the pull-down list on the left.

figure.title: SAP Installation Wizard: SAP Installation Master Location

sect2.para: In the next dialog you can select the SAP products you want to install. The offerings of available products depend on the media you received from SAP; for example, see .

For example, select CRMEhP1 — Enhancement Package 1 for SAP CRM 7.0 and click Next. Now the relevant part of the SAP media will be copied to the hard drive of the machine for the following SAP installation (after copying, see the contents of /data/SAP_CDs). This is repeated for all necessary SAP medias, with some additional simple questions.
After copying the SAP media, as step 2 enter the location of the database medium (e.g., the SAP MaxDB RDBMS); see for an NFS installation example.

figure.title: SAP Installation: Location of the Database Medium

sect2.para: Now you must provide the medium with the application server framework. As step 3 you are asked for the Path to a Kernel or Java Medium. For example, if you want to install an ABAP based system, provide the SAP Kernel for NW70 EHP1 Linux; see for an NFS installation example.

figure.title: SAP Installation: Path to a Kernel or Java Medium

sect2.para: Then finish the installation according to the product documentation.

title.guimenu: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile

sect1.para: This automated installation is driven by a user-provided &ay; profile. This scenario is suitable for experienced users who are familiar with &ay; and want to deploy their own &ay; profiles to install &sles4sap;. For more information about &ay; profiles, see the SLES &ay; Guide.

In order to use a custom &ay; script, select Install SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile from the DVD Boot Menu. Within the boot options, change the autoyast=usb:/// parameter to the location of a custom &ay; script, or enter the location when &yast; asks for it in the next dialog.

You can also choose the SAP specific pattern, the HA and WebYaST components and SAP-specific IBM Java as well in this installation scenario, but they are not preselected. You must do this yourself in your autoyast.xml file.

sect2.title: About &ay;
sect2.para: &ay; is a system for installing one or more SUSE Linux systems automatically and without user intervention. &ay; installations are performed using an &ay; profile with installation and configuration data. That profile can be created using the &ay; configuration interface and can be provided to &yast; during installation in different ways.
